div.p:
Obedience is better than Sacrifice says
Mr. E. - And I deduce from thence the
corollary than executing commissions is
better than long answers to the letters which
convey them. I have just persuaded
the old lady to carry a box for you to Mr.
Hunter's containing paper for all the roads
in Ireland - Sundry rulers and
Mr E's m valve. - My friend Mr Galloway
the Machinist & Engineer made the latter
article - He could not staunch either of
the patterns and I therefore allowed him
to fabricate a new article altogether which appears
to be very perfect. - There are two small cocks
with adjusting screws by which the slide (which
is made by his advice dove-tail fashion) can be
tightened to any degree of closeness - and
which will compensate for any wear -

The cost however is great - I copy the
bill - To a Brass dovetail frame with a gun .
metal gunmetal slide 6 1/2 long & 13/8 wide with cock and
screws. Connecting the friction roller (from the
old model) with screws & for a valve
apparatus - £ 2 .. 14 -
A Copper oblong trough & soldering
it to the brass frame - 9
£ 3 .. 3 -

Maria's Errata I carried the instant
I received them to St. Paul's but two sheets
of the second edition were already
printed off - - The remainder of the
sheets will be corrected -

For Mr E's valuable remarks & Errata
on my little work I am thankful, and
they are in good time for a second
edition - to which I fancy it has
but little chance of attaining - What
a favourable review may do is a hope
I indulge for the publisher's sake - and
that such a review is brewing I have
indistinctly heard

Mr J L F's speech has been published
but Sir Sam. Romilly who I met at
dinner at Dr Marcet's and of whom I
asked the question, says it made no
impression whatever on the house when
delivered.

Alicia joins with me in best
thanks for your fables, and both my
little boys who already point to your
picture and repeat your difficult
name, will have an additional ob-
ligation obligation to your labours - common
indeed to other children who can purchase
them - but the greatest they can owe
you and which can not be purchased
is for the improvement of their father
by your example and advice
Drawing of a hand with pointed index finger. For Maria.

Your directions have been obeyed
and 5 were quite sufficient to send
to the HillChapel mountain - Mr.
H. does not the know how to calculate
any extra expense for expediting Harrington
but he has promised to tell me candidly
when he settles with the printer - Of the
two sheets which were cancelled from the
change in the division of the volumes
you are already aware. -

Ormond & Har. Harrington>
are advertised for
publication, but I am sorry to find
that it is impossible to get them out
by the time for which I stood sponsor.
- The 25th is to usher them into the
world - and considerable expectation
is already excited - This I can learn,
but I cannot learn the public feeling
about the Dramas as my connexion
with the firm is too notorious to
allow people either to praise or
blame freely -

I cannot discover who the principle
writers are in the British Review - the
work is however known to be in the
hands of what is called the High Church
as opposed to the Methodists. -

I have sent for No. 17 to read
the article on Metrology -

figure.figDesc: Drawing of a hand with pointed index finger.

div.p:
Your little commission has been likewise
executed - it cost 2½ Guineas but
turned out entirely fruitless -

I went to the fabricator of Darwin's
pills to complain of their spicy flavour
- he told me that several gentlemen
had complained of the smell & taste
of the oil of aniseed with which they
were made up - and that to suit
their palates Oil of Cinnamon was
substituted - which made no kind
of difference in the essential effect
of the compound - but if Mr E. likes
it he will make him up a box with
the old materials.

I asked at Coulburns's about Lady
Morgan's book but the only reply he
would vouchsafe was - "It is not out
yet Sir" - He is a paltry fellow
And his Literary Gazette is -
but I won't say what till I see how
he treats Kara.
I don't know nor
have yet seen Chapple or his book -
Captn Stopford is the very man you recollect
at Bristol - I have now answered
all your questions, and the only commission
unnoticed is Mr. Gillock's whom I have
not yet been able to meet as he lives in
the Country and only comes to his office
in the morning. - Alicia and the
boys are all well - Pray have any
of Bentham's late publications been
read at Etown? - And how are they liked?
They are a little trop fort I should
imagine for the taste of the Attorney
General -

You seem in a miserable
way in Ireland - but we are not
on roses. For Drawing of a hand with pointed index finger.
William

In a long deal box particularly
recommended to Mr Hunter's
protection and through him to the
carriers sailors & agents you
will find the following articles
directed for you
